September 12, 2010: Fiction
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of a trilogy about a Swedish hacker and a journalist.
THE POSTCARD KILLERS, by James Patterson and Liza Marklund. (Little,
Brown, $27.99.) An N.Y.P.D. detective joins a Swedish reporter in a search for the
killer of young couples in Europe, including his daughter and her boyfriend.
SPIDER BONES, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $26.99.) Temperance Brennan
investigates the case of a man who seems to have died twice.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
BEARERS OF THE BLACK STAFF (LEGENDS OF SHANNARA), by Terry
Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $27.) The denizens of a valley are left vulnerable
when their protective layer of magic disappears.
STAR ISLAND, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $26.95.) A paparazzo attempting to
kidnap a drug-addled pop star grabs her stunt double by mistake.
TOUGH CUSTOMER, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $26.99.) A private
investigator pursues a deranged killer.
THE RED QUEEN, by Philippa Gregory. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $25.99.)
More intrigue during the War of the Roses; by the author of “The Other Boleyn
Girl.”
THE COBRA, by Frederick Forsyth. (Putnam, $26.95.) A former C.I.A. operative is
unleashed on the cocaine industry.
THREE STATIONS, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Simon & Schuster, $25.99.) Inspector
Arkady Renko faces corrupt Russian capitalists and bureaucrats.
I’D KNOW YOU ANYWHERE, by Laura Lippman. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $25.99.)
A man who kidnapped a 15-year-old girl contacts her from death row years later.
THE REMBRANDT AFFAIR, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $26.95.) The art restorer
and assassin Gabriel Allon discovers that there are deadly secrets behind a stolen
painting.
LAST NIGHT AT CHATEAU MARMONT, by Lauren Weisberger. (Atria, $25.99.) A
woman is challenged when her musician husband suddenly becomes a star.
JULIET, by Anne Fortier. (Ballantine, $25.) A woman digging into her Italian roots
is surprised by what she learns.
THE VIGILANTES, by W. E. B. Griffin and William E. Butterworth IV. (Putnam,
September 12, 2010
Non-Fiction
CRIMES AGAINST LIBERTY, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery, $29.95.) A political
indictment of the Obama presidency.
SH*T MY DAD SAYS, by Justin Halpern. (It Books/HarperCollins, $15.99.) A
coming-of-age memoir organized around the musings, purveyed on Twitter, of the
author’s father.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed — it has to do with luck and opportunity — from the author of “Blink.”
THE IMMORTAL LIFE OF HENRIETTA LACKS, by Rebecca Skloot. (Crown,
$26.) Race, poverty and science intertwine in the story of the woman whose
cancer cells were cultured without her permission in 1951 and have supported a
mountain of research undertaken since then.
EMPIRE OF THE SUMMER MOON, by S. C. Gwynne. (Scribner, $27.50.) The
story of Quanah Parker, the last and greatest chief of the Comanches.
THE BIG SHORT, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $27.95.) The people who saw the
real estate crash coming and made billions from their foresight.
LET'S TAKE THE LONG WAY HOME, by Gail Caldwell. (Random House, $23.) A
tribute to a deep friendship between two women.
THE OBAMA DIARIES, by Laura Ingraham. (Threshold Editions, $25.) A satirical
fictional journal with commentary, by the conservative political commentator.
COMMITTED, by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Viking, $26.95.) The author of “Eat, Pray,
Love” wrestles with, and overcomes, her ambivalence about marriage.
CHELSEA CHELSEA BANG BANG, by Chelsea Handler. (Grand Central,
$25.99.) More humorous personal essays.
BORN TO RUN, by Christopher McDougall. (Knopf, $24.95.) Secrets of distance
running from a Mexican Indian tribe.
PACKING FOR MARS, by Mary Roach. (Norton, $25.95.) A humorous
investigation of life without gravity in the space program, by the author of “Stiff”
and “Bonk.”
SLIDING INTO HOME, by Kendra Wilkinson with Jon Warech. (Gallery, $26.) The
life of the reality TV star and former Playboy cover model.
THE TENTH PARALLEL, by Eliza Griswold. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) An
interpretive circuit of the swath of the globe where Christianity and Islam meet.
